title: The Hawaiian story of the wind keepers - Sydney Iaukea

multiple-choice.question: Who is La'amaomao in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: The Hawaiian goddess of the sea.

options.label: B
options.text: The Hawaiian goddess of the wind.

options.label: C
options.text: The Hawaiian goddess of the earth.

options.label: D
options.text: The Hawaiian goddess of the sun.

multiple-choice.question: What was passed down from La'amaomao to her grandson Paka'a?
Why did the two navigators plot against Paka'a?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Paka'a was mean to them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Paka'a was better at navigating than they were.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Paka'a had a higher position in the kingdom.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Paka'a had more wealth than they did.

multiple-choice.question: Where did Paka'a take refuge after being stripped of his land and privileges?
What did Paka'a teach his son Kuapaka'a?

options.label: D
options.text: How to navigate using the stars.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Kuapaka'a unleash a storm on the king's fleet?

options.label: B
options.text: To test the king's loyalty and dedication.

options.label: C
options.text: To get revenge on the two navigators.

multiple-choice.question: What did Kuapaka'a wager in the canoe race against the eight fishermen?
Who helped Kuapaka'a win the canoe race?
Why did Kuapaka'a reveal his identity to the king?

options.label: A
options.text: To get revenge on the king.

options.label: B
options.text: To test the king's loyalty and dedication.

options.label: C
options.text: To have the king prove his commitment to Paka'a.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Paka'a's return to the kingdom?

options.label: C
options.text: His lands and position were restored.
